div.p: S. D. In my recent letters, I informed your piety about the efforts and books of Brentius and his duke sent to France.
Now I am very anxious for the brothers in France, lest anything adverse happens to them; for in Lucerne, in our vicinity, new soldiers are being recruited to be led into France.
Many fear a massacre is being prepared for the faithful; many say the Franco-English war is flaring up again.
There are those who say the king is coming to Lyon.
I can neither think nor say what it is; I only warn in advance that soldiers are being recruited in Lucerne.
For your vigilance, ensure that the leading men in France and those who need to know this do not remain ignorant of it.
If I am anxious in vain, forgive me for this; I certainly love the churches of France and will not cease to warn them, I will love them forever.
The brothers and all the colleagues greet you.
Greet Mr. Beza, Mr. Jonville, and the others.
To the most illustrious man, Mr. John Calvin, faithful minister of the church of Geneva, my esteemed lord and dearest brother.
